head.title: United States Keeps Its Lead Over Japan

hedline.hl1: United States Keeps Its Lead Over Japan

abstract.p: LPGA players split six matches with their Japanese counterparts for 7-5 lead after two rounds in Cisco World Ladies Challenge in Narita, Japan (S)

block.p: The L.P.G.A. split six matches with its Japanese counterpart yesterday for a 7-5 lead after two rounds in the $765,000 Cisco World Ladies Challenge in Narita, Japan.
The L.P.G.A. needs five victories and a tie in 12 stroke-play matches today to keep alive its 16-year winning streak and win the title for the 20th time in 22 years.
The L.P.G.A. split six matches with its Japanese counterpart yesterday for a 7-5 lead after two rounds in the $765,000 Cisco World Ladies Challenge in Narita, Japan.
The L.P.G.A. needs five victories and a tie in 12 stroke-play matches today to keep alive its 16-year winning streak and win the title for the 20th time in 22 years.
The team captain, Annika Sorenstam, a 23-time tournament winner, and Sophie Gustafson beat Akiko Fukushima and Kasumi Fujii, 63-71, at the 6,396-yard, par-72 Sosei Country Club course.
Lorie Kane, who was last year's captain, and Se Ri Pak edged Kaori Higo and Hiromi Kobayashi, 67-68, while Cristie Kerr and Becky Iverson beat Junko Yasui and Orie Fujino, 64-70.
Yuri Fudoh, this season's leading money winner in Japan, and Tseng Hsiu-feng outscored Rosie Jones and Sherri Steinhauer, 68-70.
Aki Nakano and Ku Ok-hee defeated Carin Koch and Nancy Scranton, 63-68, while Midori Yoneyama and Aki Takamura led throughout en route to a 65-67 victory over Michele Redman and Charlotta Sorenstam.
The first two rounds featured six four-ball stroke-play matches per day, while today's play consists of 12 individual stroke-play singles matches.
ROOKIE LEADS ITALIAN OPEN: The European PGA Tour rookie Ian Poulter birdied five of the last seven holes yesterday at the Italian Open to take a three-stroke lead heading into the final round.

Poulter's seven-under-par 65 dropped him to 18 under at the $830,000 tournament. Poulter, a 24-year-old Englishman, is battling for rookie of the year honors with Alastair Forsyth of Scotland, who did not make the cut here.
Francisco Cea followed up Friday's course-record 63 with a 68 and is tied for second place. Ricardo Gonzalez, Van Phillips and Roger Wessels are also at 15 under.
Gordon Brand Jr. carded a 66 and joins overnight co-leaders Elliot Boult and Richard Green another shot back.
INMAN LEADS BY TWO SHOTS: Two-time defending champion Joe Inman shot a 3-under-par 68 yesterday and maintained a two-stroke lead over Mike McCullough in the SBC Senior Classic.
Inman is trying to become the fifth player in Senior PGA Tour history to win the same tournament three consecutive years.
McCullough's 68 left him at 7-under 135, one stroke in front of Larry Nelson, who had a 64, Jim Thorpe, who had a 66, and Stewart Ginn, who had a 67.
Inman had three birdies at the 6,583-yard Wilshire Country Club course, including a 25-foot putt on No. 12.
